overview:
## Discussion

If an object has an associated restoration class, the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIObjectRestoration/object(withRestorationIdentifierPath:coder:)] method of that class is called during state restoration. That method is responsible for returning the object that matches the provided path identifier information. If this property is`nil`, the object must already exist and be registered with the state restoration engine so that it can be found implicitly. You can register the object using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIApplication/registerObject(forStateRestoration:restorationIdentifier:)] method at launch time.

The restoration class must conform to the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIObjectRestoration] protocol.

# objectRestorationClass

**Instance Property**

The class responsible for creating this object when restoring the app’s state.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor optional var objectRestorationClass: (any UIObjectRestoration.Type)? { get }
```

## Discussion

If an object has an associated restoration class, the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIObjectRestoration/object(withRestorationIdentifierPath:coder:)] method of that class is called during state restoration. That method is responsible for returning the object that matches the provided path identifier information. If this property is`nil`, the object must already exist and be registered with the state restoration engine so that it can be found implicitly. You can register the object using the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIApplication/registerObject(forStateRestoration:restorationIdentifier:)] method at launch time.

The restoration class must conform to the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIObjectRestoration] protocol.

## Accessing the object information

- **restorationParent**: The parent object used to scope the current object.
